Situation1: They make weekly phone calls to update their parents on life events and ask about their well-being.
Expectation2: Maintain passenger safety and provide assistance during service.
Situation2: The passenger emergency alarm has been activated due to a medical emergency in the train.
Story: My phone buzzed in my pocket just as I was pulling into the next station. It was Sunday evening—my usual time to call Mom and Dad. I could almost hear Mom’s gentle reminder from last week: “Don’t forget to call, even if you’re busy.” I knew how much they looked forward to these calls, how they worried if I missed even one. But before I could even unlock my phone, the emergency alarm blared through the train. The intercom crackled with urgency: “Medical emergency in car three.” Instantly, my training kicked in. I had to stay focused, keep the passengers calm, and coordinate with emergency services. But as I reached for the radio, my phone vibrated again—Mom, calling this time. My heart twisted. I wanted to reassure her, to hear Dad’s voice, to be the attentive son they needed. But right now, dozens of passengers depended on me to act quickly and keep them safe. I stood frozen for a moment, torn between the voice of my family and the responsibility echoing through the train.
